intro: Lupinus vallicola var. apricus, commonly known as the Sierra lupine, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stems and clusters of pea-like, violet-blue flowers. The plant has palmately divided leaves with a silvery-blue appearance due to fine hairs. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in open meadows and grasslands. Lupinus vallicola var. apricus plays an important role in stabilizing soil and supporting local pollinator populations.
